title: Rotational equilibrium - three forces on a beam

content.question: A beam of uniform mass density can rotate freely about a support pivot located under its midpoint, as shown in the figure. Three non-zero forces, <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, are exerted downward on the beam. Forces <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are applied at either end of the beam, and force <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is applied somewhere between the pivot and <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>. When all forces are applied the beam stays in rotational equilibrium. Which of the following claims about the force magnitudes must be correct, and what reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub 1 is less than F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> has a longer lever arm than <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, so it must be smaller in order to contribute a torque of equal magnitude.

<math alttext="F sub 1 is less than F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> contributes a torque to counteract the torques from both <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and the weight of the beam.

<math alttext="F sub 3 is less than F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the net force on each side of the pivot must be equal for the beam to be in rotational equilibrium.

<math alttext="F sub 3 is less than F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are the same distance from the pivot, and <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> contributes a torque in the same direction as <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub 3 is less than F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are the same distance from the pivot, and <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> contributes a torque in the same direction as <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>.
